description: Youngjin Yoo has been studying the digitalization of physical products and services for many years. Success will not be as simple as making products smart and connected or enabling a service digitally through apps and webs; it will require deep "digital first" design. In this interview, Yoo discusses the Digital First framework he has created and how it can be...
text:
Youngjin Yoo has been studying the digitalization of physical products and
services for many years. Success will not be as simple as making products
smart and connected or enabling a service digitally through apps and webs; it
will require deep "digital first" design. In this interview, Yoo discusses the
Digital First framework he has created and how it can be applied. He also
observes that physical product companies have real advantages as the providers
of what consumers actually consume.

Jim Euchner [JE]: You've created a number of useful digital value creation
frameworks, including the Digital First framework. I'd like to start by
discussing your thoughts on using these frameworks for driving digital value
for physical product companies.

Youngjin Yoo [YY]: When the management scholarly community first started
talking about the importance of digital assets and digital innovations, it
unleashed the concept of digital innovation that focused on the use of digital
assets. Given the generative and dynamic nature of digital technology, people
began using the term "digital innovation" in different ways, and its meaning
wasn't always clear. The early studies on digital innovation often focused on
pure digital products--on users who engage with computers or smartphones to
use online search, digital media, or social media. These products enjoy all
the nice properties of digital assets, such as zero marginal cost of
production and non-rivalry of consumption. As it is often said, the pure
digital world can look as if it is "frictionless."

But now digital technology is becoming part of all products and services--not
just in the pure digital online world but in the real physical world as well--
and there is a fundamental shift in how we should think about digital
innovation. What I came to realize was that we've been completely missing the
importance--even the necessity--of the physicality of digital innovation. That
insight gave me an opportunity to pivot; when everyone else was talking about
the digital side of digital innovation, I felt we needed to think more about
the physical aspects of digital innovation and the importance of physical
assets in the process. At the end of the day, it's not a pure digital
experience that really matters because most companies cannot create and
capture value unless their offering is consumed by users, and in many cases,
that consumption requires some conversion of digital information into a
physical manifestation.

That realization became crystal clear to me when I started talking to
companies like Goodyear, Ikon, Timken, and LG. To some degree these companies
feel disadvantaged, and they often focus on what they don't think they have to
digitally innovate--but this is deficiency-oriented thinking. By focusing on
what they do not have, they neglect what they already do have. The early
generation of Silicon Valley companies, like Google and Facebook, never had to
leave the digital space to create and capture value. The second generation of
companies, such as Uber and Amazon, are successful cases of crossing the
boundary between digital and physical. As these companies, and others like
Airbnb and now WeWork, come from the digital space to the physical space, they
are starting to realize how hard it is. A third generation will be those
industrial companies that embrace Digital First. Amazon's acquisition of Whole
Foods is a specific example of the difficulty of moving from the digital to
the physical space. Amazon was probably hoping to fully integrate its Whole
Foods corporation into its Amazon operation, but the company hasn't been able
to do that yet. Amazon and Whole Foods remain, by and large, separate
entities. All we get as consumers, for example, is a small discount for Amazon
Prime members at Whole Foods; there is no deep connection. This example shows
the challenge that companies face in converting digital insight into physical
consumption. And that, I think, is where the opportunity lies.

The advantage an industrial company has is that it owns physical touchpoints--
a customer base, a physical sales channel, physical products, and so on. Not
every one of these assets will become strategic leverage points, but some of
them can be quite useful. The question is how to leverage the physical assets
and combine them with digital capabilities to create new value in a way that
we could not do in the past. That's the initial starting point for the Digital
First argument.

The real battleground in the coming decade will be in this Digital First
space. Traditional companies always think about the physical first, and when
they move to digital, they think about digital as secondary. Digital native
companies, on the other hand, started as digital-only companies, but they are
now thinking about moving into physical space. Many still downplay the
challenges as they seek to deploy digital assets in the physical space. They
would like to believe that they can make physicality go away or at least
pretend as if it does not exist.

Unfortunately, in the physical world that we live in, we have things like the
law of gravity. There are frictions in this world; things have weights and
heights; they occupy real space. An app might behave the same way after a
million uses, but an Uber driver will become really tired after 10 hours of
driving. I think native digital companies are beginning to understand just how
difficult it is to move things and people in accordance with what their
algorithms dictate. I believe that physical companies need to become Digital
First, but they need to come at it from a different angle than the digital
natives are.

It's interesting to watch the dynamics as this unfolds. Digital native
companies are rapidly acquiring physical assets and physical companies are
rapidly acquiring digital assets. In a way, it's a foot race to see who will
figure out how these two things work best together. I don't think there is
anyone who has completely gotten it right. The Digital First framework we have
developed tries to help physical companies to think through what it is that
they need to do to succeed digitally. That's the motivation for the framework.

JE: It seems like a lot of physical companies see digital as an add-on: adding
intelligence to an existing product or adding a digital experience or an app
to a physical product. Your work has taken the view that the physical product
should be thought of from a digital point of view at the point of conception.
The design of a product needs to change in a way that makes it possible for
its consumption to be fundamentally different. Digital First products are
"generative" because they evolve and spark engagement, not just use.

YY: There are a couple of things that I would like to emphasize. The first is
what I have termed "deferred binding," which is what enables products to be
generative. Manufacturing such products is different from the traditional
manufacturing process. Traditionally, when you produce a physical product,
what the product does and how it does it is determined by the designers at the
point of design and is fixed throughout the manufacturing process, right up
through the buying point. Users are not part of the ecosystem at all. The
value creation chain ends when you sell the product. You must capture all the
value at the point of sale.

With this traditional value chain model, there is no way of knowing what
people actually do once they have the product. The idea of deferred binding is
that we can digitally gain insights into what users want and need at or near
the point of use, then we can digitally design an offering to meet the
perceived needs, and finally physically mobilize resources to meet that
particular need. And, this is not a one-time event--rather, it is an ongoing
and recurring engagement. At the high level, that's what the Digital First
framework is about.

Many products will still need to be manufactured and distributed. But instead
of the sale being the end point, with one-time value creation and capture, the
sale should be seen as the beginning of an ongoing and recurring value-
creation relationship with the users. The issues are: Who will have better
insights on user needs? Who will be able to generate better services to meet
the perceived needs? Who will be able to physically meet the needs? Answering
these questions will require critical strategic capabilities that firms will
need to have to implement their Digital First strategy. Some of the
capabilities might come from me as a manufacturer, and some of them might come
from other people. Some of them might be digital, and some of them might be
physical but, as the designer and manufacturer, I take the role of determining
what combination of these things are necessary to meet your needs as a
customer, and then I give them to you. At a very high level, that's what
deferred binding is.

JE: Your framework helps firms that develop physical products to think about
how to make their companies digital. In my experience, although physical
product companies have a strong sense at a high level that they need to become
digital, they are not sure how to do so. You have created a four-part
framework that considers design through the lenses of time, place, artifacts,
and the people who are using them. The user experience is at the center of
that framework.

You also talk in terms of the offline/online (or the physical/ digital)
experience and the backstage and frontstage (the user experience and what's
necessary to deliver it). I think it's a powerful design tool. Your framework
would change the way design is practiced. It builds on, but goes beyond, the
traditional "understand customer needs and fill them" framework.

YY: In the Digital First framework, users take actions in the context of
particular configurations of time, space, artifacts, and people, and the
consequence of those actions shape experiences. Those experiences determine
the value created. The computational tools, such as the Internet of Things
(IoT), mobile/wearable, predictive analytics, and generative algorithms, are
really about how the different actors create or shape our experience by
digitally mediating that experience in time, space, tools, and with other
people. It's really not much different from what we do when we map out a
customer's journey map. However, manufacturing companies often use journey
maps in a very limited way, to understand how someone purchases their product
and how the purchase journey ends, for example.

What I want to do is to go beyond this--to digitally engage with users in an
ongoing way. A company needs to understand the user experience deeply and
dynamically, and then it can decide how it can be part of shaping users'
activities and experiences over time. You want to understand what people do
before and after specific events. The computed experience should be seen as a
series of snapshots of a computed experience diagram. When this is done, the
users' experiences can be understood as a series of unfolding events across
time and space that users engage within physical time and space constraints,
partially mediated through digital tools. The experiences, in turn, produce
digital trace data. Given this, each company needs to think about its way of
shaping a particular experience. If the users value the experience through use
of a product, they're more likely to pay a premium or switch from a competitor
to the company's experience.

The journey map for Digital First products should not represent just a one-
time journey, but an ongoing and recurring set of events. It allows you to
think differently about ways to create and capture value (Figure 1).

JE: Can you give an example? What would the process be to get to the point
where you achieved the ideal of having the experience of the product situated
in both time and place?

YY: Let's take an example from the world of music. In a movie there is always
a soundtrack that makes the scene more compelling and dramatic. But in my
normal life, there's nothing like that. To compensate, we often create our own
"soundtrack" with earphones and headsets, voices of family and friends, and
TVs and music players. What if there were a company that curated soundtracks
for your life? They would create a layer of experience that depended on time,
space, artifacts, and people. Throughout the day, all that company would think
about would be creating the best listening experience for you. From the moment
you wake up until the moment you go to bed, all day long, it would curate your
sound experience.

It wouldn't matter what medium you were using to listen with, or whether you
were in the bathroom, the shower, the car, in your office, or using your
AirPods--it would know exactly what you would be likely to listen to, and
would then curate and deliver the content to you, wherever you were. Spotify
probably comes closest to this, but I don't think that it quite delivers
because the company doesn't really think through the physical space of the
auditory experience.

Think about the moments in your life. When I wake up, I am in bed; then I go
and run; then I take a shower; and then I drive to work. Is it possible that
Spotify could know the context of my activity at each point and what I liked
to listen to for every single activity? I want to listen to bird noises when I
wake up; I want to listen to music when I shower; I want to listen to
different music when I run; I want to listen to NPR when I drive; and I want
to talk to my wife when we have breakfast together. Why can't somebody curate
that in an interesting way so that I don't have to do anything, so that my
life is like a movie soundtrack all the time?

Is it possible? I think so. I'm looking for a startup who would declare, "We
are the sound engineers of your life." Nothing in this vision is
prefabricated; there is no CD, no channel; it's dynamic, it's ongoing, and
it's curated. That is an experiential product from a sound perspective.

A company that creates such a platform needs a way of enveloping these
activities--like a semi-marketplace--and then it needs to let third-party
complementors compete with each other within that platform. The users will not
have to go to other places to find these providers; the platform will have a
collection of complementors that they think would be useful for you, and you
will choose from that.

Digital platform companies will be very different from the traditional
hierarchical companies, which offer one product or serve one market. These
digital platform companies will make products and services that are highly
contingent upon your needs, using algorithms to determine those needs
depending on context and third-party complementors to deliver them. This is
where I think the world is going.

JE: That's the best description I've heard of what a digital platform for a
physical company might actually be. There are so many people talking about
platforms, and I think they are struggling to convey just how to think about
them.

In your work, you talk about the difference between products, which require
early binding, and platforms, which enable deferred binding. You also talk
about closed versus open systems, and the potential of opening up a platform.
The platform is designed to enable the full, context-dependent experience, and
it brings in partners where necessary to make the experience happen. Am I
accurately reflecting the model?

YY: Absolutely. So what is a platform? A platform is a semi-market. It is a
market in that there are multiple complementors that are competing for your
attention. It is a semi-market because it requires the physical platform to
exist. Apple's ecosystem requires Apple's product; it does not exist without
iOS and Apple's hardware products. Second, it is a semi-market because it is
100 percent open. The firm that owns the platform sets the rules.

Now why does this matter? Users always combine multiple products and services
to create their own value. But if a platform company can understand the full
user experience in an area, the full breadth of activities that users
participate in, and the resources that they use to do so, it can create--and
capture--a lot more value.

Some time ago Oliver Hart received a Nobel Prize for a very simple insight:
you cannot capture value without ownership of property. When Nike sells shoes,
for example, it loses ownership of the property (the shoes). All the value
that the user creates by using the property is captured by the user. This
value is often larger than the value Nike could ever think about capturing as
a product company. That is why users buy products. The price we pay, and the
value Nike captures, must be smaller than the value we generate by using their
products. Users bring additional resources to create value in that process.

Now imagine that Nike treated its product as a platform with its own digital
resources, and that the company continued to have at least partial ownership
of the digital resources after the sale. If Nike were able to use digital
resources to understand how users wanted to create value, and if it could help
users fulfill their needs by providing useful complementers, the company would
have a legitimate reason to capture value either from the users or
complementors. The transaction would not be just about the shoes; it would
include fashion and sports competitions and social factors. Each of these is a
place where more value might be created in context.

But before now companies have never had the visibility to understand what
people actually do, and they have had no way of mobilizing the necessary
resources to help them. As a result, product companies have relinquished
ownership of the assets through a product sale, so they have left everything
else on the table; they have captured a tiny fraction of the value created.
With digital platforms, firms do not have to do that anymore, so firms with
digital platforms will be much more valuable.

In many ways, this is not any different from traditional B2B companies that
have turned to system-solution selling. The B2C companies tell their
customers, "I have a solution for you for your process or your function; you
just pay me X, and I will bring together a whole bunch of business partners
who will sell you the components of the services you need as part of the total
solution." If companies do this right, customers are willing to pay for it.

The idea underlying platforms is that, as a product company, you create semi-
markets within which you retain certain ownership of the digital assets that
underpin the platform. Then you bring together the players that you think will
add value for the users, and you orchestrate them for the users according to
their particular needs at a particular time and place. The users can choose
which parts they want to consume, and the final product will be different for
different users--that's what we mean by deferred binding. Note that it's not
the product itself that undergoes deferred binding; it's the orchestration of
the experience of using the product--the co-creation of value--that is being
deferred.

If your digital platform ecosystem becomes too big, however, and there are too
many complementors, the platform will need to reduce the complexity of the
choice. This is why I believe that companies will move in the direction of
curating these "playlists" of activities for end users, without the users
themselves having to directly choose from all the complementors. A Spotify
playlist is a very prescient service offering. Think about the difference
between the old iTunes and Spotify. With iPod and iTunes, you download music
(from music labels as complementors), and you build playlists. With Spotify,
playlists are already built, and Spotify keeps recommending playlists you
should play depending on the context. This will be a model that many will have
to follow, because users are essentially lazy; if a platform can make a choice
that I believe that I might like better than the one I would make myself, I
will be willing to pay for it. The bundle of carefully curated activities
together with necessary complementary resources will produce an experience
superior to simple use of the product.

In many ways this is an evolution of the idea of markets. Companies create
value by identifying and meeting needs in the marketplace. The mass production
model sees only one need in a single market and needs only one type of
response to fulfill it. The market segmentation model breaks the market down
into sub-segments, and manufacturers create the capacity to respond to more
diverse needs for these segments. Personalization means that each customer is
its own market.

But this is not the end game. Companies like Amazon want to know you better
than you know yourself. They want to evolve their model of you as you change.
Your needs in the morning are different than your needs in the evening, so I
cannot even treat you as a single market; personalization is no longer enough.
You yourself are multiple markets, and I need to be able to mobilize my
resources accordingly. To do this, whether a company is digital or not, it
needs two capabilities--a sensing capability and a responding capability.

The point that I'm making with Digital First is that when you digitize these
two capabilities--your ability to sense precisely and in a timely way, and
your ability to mobilize resources--you are going to be better than companies
that don't. You can do this by using your product as a baseline from which to
build a platform, because you have that asset. For example, Samsung has TV
units in more households in the United States than anyone else. Why can't
Samsung use that? They know when somebody is watching TV and they need to ask
other questions: What else does this person do when they watch TV? What is the
journey around TV watching experiences that we as a consumer want to mobilize?
These questions open up something bigger than the idea of a Smart TV. What is
important is what is happening in the living room during the watching of TV
that allows Samsung to co-create value as part of that experience. Maybe the
complementors are chicken and beer while you're watching a football game, for
example, not some feature of the TV itself.

JE: In your model you talk about the digital value loop. Each experience is
part of a loop. You have also observed that there are five design choices that
are important: creating a loop, the velocity of the loop, the veracity of the
loop, the depth of the loop, and the granularity of the loop. Can you talk
about these design choices?

YY: A digital value loop is essentially a company's ability to sense the
contingency in the world and respond to it. Many companies have not created
any loops, at all. They may get a delayed sensing of the environment since,
once they sell a product, they get a market response through sales numbers.
They may also have once-a-year focus groups, for example, but these are
really, really delayed loops.

A connected product offers you the ability to monitor the actual use in close
to real time. This creates a loop, which is essential, but the velocity of the
loop depends on your ability to respond to the signal. If feedback is received
on a daily basis versus a weekly or monthly basis, that creates a very
different basis for an organization to respond to the data.

The veracity of the loop is also important. Veracity refers to the reality of
what users are doing and care about in the loop. Computer sensors are not real
human beings; they are just seeing the stream of data coming in, and an
algorithm is inferring what is happening in the real world. But how do we
understand if a data stream coming in from users is actually the real data
stream that is reflective of a certain activity? An example might help. When
the Pokemon Go game came out, it was connected with a pedometer to encourage
kids to walk, but my son just shook the pedometer. The pedometer didn't know
whether my son was actually walking or just shaking it. That's a veracity
issue. Facebook has veracity problem in its loop because it is cost-free for
people to lie; Amazon doesn't, because ordering products just to confuse
Amazon's algorithms costs money.

Depth and breadth refer to how deeply you go with your analysis of the loop.
Do you consider just music, or also other kinds of sound experiences? Do you
include news, for example? Phone conversations? There are different depths
that might be considered. Breadth refers to the different modalities of
experience. In the imaginary digital soundtrack service that I talked about
earlier, the breadth refers to the media, like audio, visual, and physical
media. There are different dimensionalities of experiences we can mediate with
different media. The media could include sounds related to entertainment,
news, or work.

Granularity refers to how pinpointed the information is. The system might
understand the sound decibel level of my entire house, or a room in the house,
or within my body reach. Think of Airbnb. You use Airbnb because you need a
house, a home, a kitchen, a dining table. If I want to host a party, I may not
need a whole house; I just need a dining room with a dining table. Can Airbnb
sense and respond to users' needs at that resolution? The goal is to sense
what the customer really needs and then to match that with the precise
resources required, minimizing waste.

JE: You talk about both sensing and responding. For responding, you have used
the metaphor of printing. Obviously, printing isn't just printing a document
or a thing--it is a broader concept in your meaning of the term. Can you talk
about what you mean by printing as it ties in with co-creation at the point of
use?

YY: Printing in my way of thinking is a conversion of digital insights into an
actual physical manifestation of some kind to create value to users in the
physical world. Once Spotify has insight about what you like to listen to, for
example, that insight needs to be translated into actual music. The printing
is done when the beats hit the airwave. The whole idea is the materialization
of computed insights into a physical rendering of some form, something which
is of value to users and that they can actually consume. To me, that's
printing.

This notion of printing is related to the concept of procrastinated binding.
Printing used to be done massively at the point of manufacturing. It was at
manufacturing that all the insight from market research was converted into
design and became a physical product. Value was captured when the product was
sold. That was the end of the journey, and the producer didn't see or capture
any of the value created during use. In the Digital First view, there is still
a product, but the value capture is not only at the point of purchase, but
also during use throughout the life of the product. The printing is delayed or
procrastinated. And it is recurring. The printing involves mobilizing the
different resources that are needed to create value in use for the customers.
By necessity, it involves not only my product but also the products or
services of other parties. The coordination and mobilization of the different
parties and resources are done through algorithms, and they are done in run-
time. As a manufacturer I want to be the one who coordinates the mobilization
of those resources. I don't want to leave it to the user, because then I will
not participate in creating value in use, and I won't have the right to
capture any of the value. I also don't want to cede this role to other parties
because they will be in the position to capture most of the value. I'd rather
be the one who coordinates the experience, and I want to earn that role
because I have better insight about customer needs.

JE: One more question. How should Digital First thinking affect what leaders
of R&D or product development in physical product companies do? How should
they think about their roles going forward?

YY: I think that the idea of traditional R&D needs to change. People need to
get out of their labs and go into users' houses, because if they really want
to do this Digital First transformation, the value is created at the point of
use. How can you create a platform without seeing and understanding that
action? The point of value creation is no longer at your factory; the point of
value creation is at the point of consumption and use. As an R&D leader, you
had better be there; you had better really understand what can be done beyond
the product to deliver the experience. That is the most important, big thing
R&D leaders need to do.

The IoT can be viewed as many different things, but from an R&D perspective, I
look at IoT and connected products not only as a delivery platform but also as
an R&D partner. If we are able to get rich data and feed it into analytical
engines to sense what users like to do and generate possible digital solutions
using generative algorithms, I think that we will discover a tremendous
opportunity for IoT to create very different and much better consumption
experiences. This is the big advantage that physical product companies will
have in the next generation of digital.

Jim Euchner is editor-in-chief of Research-Technology Management and Honorary
Professor at Aston University (UK). He previously held senior management
positions in innovation leadership at Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, Pitney
Bowes, and Bell Atlantic. He holds BS and MS degrees in mechanical and
aerospace engineering from Cornell and Princeton Universities, respectively,
and an MBA from Southern Methodist University.
[euchner@iriweb.org](mailto:euchner@iriweb.org)

Youngjin Yoo is the Elizabeth M. and William C. Treuhaft Professor in
Entrepreneurship and Professor of Information Systems in the Department of
Design & Innovation at the Weatherhead School of Management, Case Western
Reserve University in Cleveland, Ohio. He is the founding faculty director of
Case Western Reserve University's xLab. He is also a WBS Distinguished
Research Environment Professor at Warwick Business School (UK), a visiting
professor at the London School of Economics (UK), and an Association for
Information Systems Fellow. He has worked as an innovation architect
overseeing digital transformation at the University Hospitals of Cleveland,
one of the largest teaching hospital systems in the US. He studies digital
innovation and has published in leading academic journals such as MIS
Quarterly, Information Systems Research, Organization Science, the
Communications of the ACM, and the Academy of Management Journal.
[youngjin.yoo@case.edu](mailto:youngjin.yoo@case.edu)

DOI: 10.1080/08956308.2020.1733885

Caption: Youngjin Yoo, distinguished professor and founding faculty director
of Case Western Reserve University's xLab.

title: Digital First Thinking for Industrial Companies: An Interview with Youngjin Yoo: Youngjin Yoo talks with Jim Euchner about digital value creation for physical products and the Digital First framework.(CONVERSATIONS)(Interview)
html:
Youngjin Yoo has been studying the digitalization of physical products and services for many years. Success will not be as simple as making products smart and connected or enabling a service digitally through apps and webs; it will require deep "digital first" design. In this interview, Yoo discusses the Digital First framework he has created and how it can be applied. He also observes that physical product companies have real advantages as the providers of what consumers actually consume.

Jim Euchner [JE]: You've created a number of useful digital value creation frameworks, including the Digital First framework. I'd like to start by discussing your thoughts on using these frameworks for driving digital value for physical product companies.

Youngjin Yoo [YY]: When the management scholarly community first started talking about the importance of digital assets and digital innovations, it unleashed the concept of digital innovation that focused on the use of digital assets. Given the generative and dynamic nature of digital technology, people began using the term "digital innovation" in different ways, and its meaning wasn't always clear. The early studies on digital innovation often focused on pure digital products--on users who engage with computers or smartphones to use online search, digital media, or social media. These products enjoy all the nice properties of digital assets, such as zero marginal cost of production and non-rivalry of consumption. As it is often said, the pure digital world can look as if it is "frictionless."

But now digital technology is becoming part of all products and services--not just in the pure digital online world but in the real physical world as well--and there is a fundamental shift in how we should think about digital innovation. What I came to realize was that we've been completely missing the importance--even the necessity--of the physicality of digital innovation. That insight gave me an opportunity to pivot; when everyone else was talking about the digital side of digital innovation, I felt we needed to think more about the physical aspects of digital innovation and the importance of physical assets in the process. At the end of the day, it's not a pure digital experience that really matters because most companies cannot create and capture value unless their offering is consumed by users, and in many cases, that consumption requires some conversion of digital information into a physical manifestation.

That realization became crystal clear to me when I started talking to companies like Goodyear, Ikon, Timken, and LG. To some degree these companies feel disadvantaged, and they often focus on what they don't think they have to digitally innovate--but this is deficiency-oriented thinking. By focusing on what they do not have, they neglect what they already do have. The early generation of Silicon Valley companies, like Google and Facebook, never had to leave the digital space to create and capture value. The second generation of companies, such as Uber and Amazon, are successful cases of crossing the boundary between digital and physical. As these companies, and others like Airbnb and now WeWork, come from the digital space to the physical space, they are starting to realize how hard it is. A third generation will be those industrial companies that embrace Digital First. Amazon's acquisition of Whole Foods is a specific example of the difficulty of moving from the digital to the physical space. Amazon was probably hoping to fully integrate its Whole Foods corporation into its Amazon operation, but the company hasn't been able to do that yet. Amazon and Whole Foods remain, by and large, separate entities. All we get as consumers, for example, is a small discount for Amazon Prime members at Whole Foods; there is no deep connection. This example shows the challenge that companies face in converting digital insight into physical consumption. And that, I think, is where the opportunity lies.

The advantage an industrial company has is that it owns physical touchpoints--a customer base, a physical sales channel, physical products, and so on. Not every one of these assets will become strategic leverage points, but some of them can be quite useful. The question is how to leverage the physical assets and combine them with digital capabilities to create new value in a way that we could not do in the past. That's the initial starting point for the Digital First argument.

The real battleground in the coming decade will be in this Digital First space. Traditional companies always think about the physical first, and when they move to digital, they think about digital as secondary. Digital native companies, on the other hand, started as digital-only companies, but they are now thinking about moving into physical space. Many still downplay the challenges as they seek to deploy digital assets in the physical space. They would like to believe that they can make physicality go away or at least pretend as if it does not exist.

Unfortunately, in the physical world that we live in, we have things like the law of gravity. There are frictions in this world; things have weights and heights; they occupy real space. An app might behave the same way after a million uses, but an Uber driver will become really tired after 10 hours of driving. I think native digital companies are beginning to understand just how difficult it is to move things and people in accordance with what their algorithms dictate. I believe that physical companies need to become Digital First, but they need to come at it from a different angle than the digital natives are.

It's interesting to watch the dynamics as this unfolds. Digital native companies are rapidly acquiring physical assets and physical companies are rapidly acquiring digital assets. In a way, it's a foot race to see who will figure out how these two things work best together. I don't think there is anyone who has completely gotten it right. The Digital First framework we have developed tries to help physical companies to think through what it is that they need to do to succeed digitally. That's the motivation for the framework.

JE: It seems like a lot of physical companies see digital as an add-on: adding intelligence to an existing product or adding a digital experience or an app to a physical product. Your work has taken the view that the physical product should be thought of from a digital point of view at the point of conception. The design of a product needs to change in a way that makes it possible for its consumption to be fundamentally different. Digital First products are "generative" because they evolve and spark engagement, not just use.

YY: There are a couple of things that I would like to emphasize. The first is what I have termed "deferred binding," which is what enables products to be generative. Manufacturing such products is different from the traditional manufacturing process. Traditionally, when you produce a physical product, what the product does and how it does it is determined by the designers at the point of design and is fixed throughout the manufacturing process, right up through the buying point. Users are not part of the ecosystem at all. The value creation chain ends when you sell the product. You must capture all the value at the point of sale.

With this traditional value chain model, there is no way of knowing what people actually do once they have the product. The idea of deferred binding is that we can digitally gain insights into what users want and need at or near the point of use, then we can digitally design an offering to meet the perceived needs, and finally physically mobilize resources to meet that particular need. And, this is not a one-time event--rather, it is an ongoing and recurring engagement. At the high level, that's what the Digital First framework is about.

Many products will still need to be manufactured and distributed. But instead of the sale being the end point, with one-time value creation and capture, the sale should be seen as the beginning of an ongoing and recurring value-creation relationship with the users. The issues are: Who will have better insights on user needs? Who will be able to generate better services to meet the perceived needs? Who will be able to physically meet the needs? Answering these questions will require critical strategic capabilities that firms will need to have to implement their Digital First strategy. Some of the capabilities might come from me as a manufacturer, and some of them might come from other people. Some of them might be digital, and some of them might be physical but, as the designer and manufacturer, I take the role of determining what combination of these things are necessary to meet your needs as a customer, and then I give them to you. At a very high level, that's what deferred binding is.

JE: Your framework helps firms that develop physical products to think about how to make their companies digital. In my experience, although physical product companies have a strong sense at a high level that they need to become digital, they are not sure how to do so. You have created a four-part framework that considers design through the lenses of time, place, artifacts, and the people who are using them. The user experience is at the center of that framework.

You also talk in terms of the offline/online (or the physical/ digital) experience and the backstage and frontstage (the user experience and what's necessary to deliver it). I think it's a powerful design tool. Your framework would change the way design is practiced. It builds on, but goes beyond, the traditional "understand customer needs and fill them" framework.

YY: In the Digital First framework, users take actions in the context of particular configurations of time, space, artifacts, and people, and the consequence of those actions shape experiences. Those experiences determine the value created. The computational tools, such as the Internet of Things (IoT), mobile/wearable, predictive analytics, and generative algorithms, are really about how the different actors create or shape our experience by digitally mediating that experience in time, space, tools, and with other people. It's really not much different from what we do when we map out a customer's journey map. However, manufacturing companies often use journey maps in a very limited way, to understand how someone purchases their product and how the purchase journey ends, for example.

What I want to do is to go beyond this--to digitally engage with users in an ongoing way. A company needs to understand the user experience deeply and dynamically, and then it can decide how it can be part of shaping users' activities and experiences over time. You want to understand what people do before and after specific events. The computed experience should be seen as a series of snapshots of a computed experience diagram. When this is done, the users' experiences can be understood as a series of unfolding events across time and space that users engage within physical time and space constraints, partially mediated through digital tools. The experiences, in turn, produce digital trace data. Given this, each company needs to think about its way of shaping a particular experience. If the users value the experience through use of a product, they're more likely to pay a premium or switch from a competitor to the company's experience.

The journey map for Digital First products should not represent just a one-time journey, but an ongoing and recurring set of events. It allows you to think differently about ways to create and capture value (Figure 1).

JE: Can you give an example? What would the process be to get to the point where you achieved the ideal of having the experience of the product situated in both time and place?

YY: Let's take an example from the world of music. In a movie there is always a soundtrack that makes the scene more compelling and dramatic. But in my normal life, there's nothing like that. To compensate, we often create our own "soundtrack" with earphones and headsets, voices of family and friends, and TVs and music players. What if there were a company that curated soundtracks for your life? They would create a layer of experience that depended on time, space, artifacts, and people. Throughout the day, all that company would think about would be creating the best listening experience for you. From the moment you wake up until the moment you go to bed, all day long, it would curate your sound experience.

It wouldn't matter what medium you were using to listen with, or whether you were in the bathroom, the shower, the car, in your office, or using your AirPods--it would know exactly what you would be likely to listen to, and would then curate and deliver the content to you, wherever you were. Spotify probably comes closest to this, but I don't think that it quite delivers because the company doesn't really think through the physical space of the auditory experience.

Think about the moments in your life. When I wake up, I am in bed; then I go and run; then I take a shower; and then I drive to work. Is it possible that Spotify could know the context of my activity at each point and what I liked to listen to for every single activity? I want to listen to bird noises when I wake up; I want to listen to music when I shower; I want to listen to different music when I run; I want to listen to NPR when I drive; and I want to talk to my wife when we have breakfast together. Why can't somebody curate that in an interesting way so that I don't have to do anything, so that my life is like a movie soundtrack all the time?

Is it possible? I think so. I'm looking for a startup who would declare, "We are the sound engineers of your life." Nothing in this vision is prefabricated; there is no CD, no channel; it's dynamic, it's ongoing, and it's curated. That is an experiential product from a sound perspective.

A company that creates such a platform needs a way of enveloping these activities--like a semi-marketplace--and then it needs to let third-party complementors compete with each other within that platform. The users will not have to go to other places to find these providers; the platform will have a collection of complementors that they think would be useful for you, and you will choose from that.

Digital platform companies will be very different from the traditional hierarchical companies, which offer one product or serve one market. These digital platform companies will make products and services that are highly contingent upon your needs, using algorithms to determine those needs depending on context and third-party complementors to deliver them. This is where I think the world is going.

JE: That's the best description I've heard of what a digital platform for a physical company might actually be. There are so many people talking about platforms, and I think they are struggling to convey just how to think about them.

In your work, you talk about the difference between products, which require early binding, and platforms, which enable deferred binding. You also talk about closed versus open systems, and the potential of opening up a platform. The platform is designed to enable the full, context-dependent experience, and it brings in partners where necessary to make the experience happen. Am I accurately reflecting the model?

YY: Absolutely. So what is a platform? A platform is a semi-market. It is a market in that there are multiple complementors that are competing for your attention. It is a semi-market because it requires the physical platform to exist. Apple's ecosystem requires Apple's product; it does not exist without iOS and Apple's hardware products. Second, it is a semi-market because it is 100 percent open. The firm that owns the platform sets the rules.

Now why does this matter? Users always combine multiple products and services to create their own value. But if a platform company can understand the full user experience in an area, the full breadth of activities that users participate in, and the resources that they use to do so, it can create--and capture--a lot more value.

Some time ago Oliver Hart received a Nobel Prize for a very simple insight: you cannot capture value without ownership of property. When Nike sells shoes, for example, it loses ownership of the property (the shoes). All the value that the user creates by using the property is captured by the user. This value is often larger than the value Nike could ever think about capturing as a product company. That is why users buy products. The price we pay, and the value Nike captures, must be smaller than the value we generate by using their products. Users bring additional resources to create value in that process.

Now imagine that Nike treated its product as a platform with its own digital resources, and that the company continued to have at least partial ownership of the digital resources after the sale. If Nike were able to use digital resources to understand how users wanted to create value, and if it could help users fulfill their needs by providing useful complementers, the company would have a legitimate reason to capture value either from the users or complementors. The transaction would not be just about the shoes; it would include fashion and sports competitions and social factors. Each of these is a place where more value might be created in context.

But before now companies have never had the visibility to understand what people actually do, and they have had no way of mobilizing the necessary resources to help them. As a result, product companies have relinquished ownership of the assets through a product sale, so they have left everything else on the table; they have captured a tiny fraction of the value created. With digital platforms, firms do not have to do that anymore, so firms with digital platforms will be much more valuable.

In many ways, this is not any different from traditional B2B companies that have turned to system-solution selling. The B2C companies tell their customers, "I have a solution for you for your process or your function; you just pay me X, and I will bring together a whole bunch of business partners who will sell you the components of the services you need as part of the total solution." If companies do this right, customers are willing to pay for it.

The idea underlying platforms is that, as a product company, you create semi-markets within which you retain certain ownership of the digital assets that underpin the platform. Then you bring together the players that you think will add value for the users, and you orchestrate them for the users according to their particular needs at a particular time and place. The users can choose which parts they want to consume, and the final product will be different for different users--that's what we mean by deferred binding. Note that it's not the product itself that undergoes deferred binding; it's the orchestration of the experience of using the product--the co-creation of value--that is being deferred.

If your digital platform ecosystem becomes too big, however, and there are too many complementors, the platform will need to reduce the complexity of the choice. This is why I believe that companies will move in the direction of curating these "playlists" of activities for end users, without the users themselves having to directly choose from all the complementors. A Spotify playlist is a very prescient service offering. Think about the difference between the old iTunes and Spotify. With iPod and iTunes, you download music (from music labels as complementors), and you build playlists. With Spotify, playlists are already built, and Spotify keeps recommending playlists you should play depending on the context. This will be a model that many will have to follow, because users are essentially lazy; if a platform can make a choice that I believe that I might like better than the one I would make myself, I will be willing to pay for it. The bundle of carefully curated activities together with necessary complementary resources will produce an experience superior to simple use of the product.

In many ways this is an evolution of the idea of markets. Companies create value by identifying and meeting needs in the marketplace. The mass production model sees only one need in a single market and needs only one type of response to fulfill it. The market segmentation model breaks the market down into sub-segments, and manufacturers create the capacity to respond to more diverse needs for these segments. Personalization means that each customer is its own market.

But this is not the end game. Companies like Amazon want to know you better than you know yourself. They want to evolve their model of you as you change. Your needs in the morning are different than your needs in the evening, so I cannot even treat you as a single market; personalization is no longer enough. You yourself are multiple markets, and I need to be able to mobilize my resources accordingly. To do this, whether a company is digital or not, it needs two capabilities--a sensing capability and a responding capability.

The point that I'm making with Digital First is that when you digitize these two capabilities--your ability to sense precisely and in a timely way, and your ability to mobilize resources--you are going to be better than companies that don't. You can do this by using your product as a baseline from which to build a platform, because you have that asset. For example, Samsung has TV units in more households in the United States than anyone else. Why can't Samsung use that? They know when somebody is watching TV and they need to ask other questions: What else does this person do when they watch TV? What is the journey around TV watching experiences that we as a consumer want to mobilize? These questions open up something bigger than the idea of a Smart TV. What is important is what is happening in the living room during the watching of TV that allows Samsung to co-create value as part of that experience. Maybe the complementors are chicken and beer while you're watching a football game, for example, not some feature of the TV itself.

JE: In your model you talk about the digital value loop. Each experience is part of a loop. You have also observed that there are five design choices that are important: creating a loop, the velocity of the loop, the veracity of the loop, the depth of the loop, and the granularity of the loop. Can you talk about these design choices?

YY: A digital value loop is essentially a company's ability to sense the contingency in the world and respond to it. Many companies have not created any loops, at all. They may get a delayed sensing of the environment since, once they sell a product, they get a market response through sales numbers. They may also have once-a-year focus groups, for example, but these are really, really delayed loops.

A connected product offers you the ability to monitor the actual use in close to real time. This creates a loop, which is essential, but the velocity of the loop depends on your ability to respond to the signal. If feedback is received on a daily basis versus a weekly or monthly basis, that creates a very different basis for an organization to respond to the data.

The veracity of the loop is also important. Veracity refers to the reality of what users are doing and care about in the loop. Computer sensors are not real human beings; they are just seeing the stream of data coming in, and an algorithm is inferring what is happening in the real world. But how do we understand if a data stream coming in from users is actually the real data stream that is reflective of a certain activity? An example might help. When the Pokemon Go game came out, it was connected with a pedometer to encourage kids to walk, but my son just shook the pedometer. The pedometer didn't know whether my son was actually walking or just shaking it. That's a veracity issue. Facebook has veracity problem in its loop because it is cost-free for people to lie; Amazon doesn't, because ordering products just to confuse Amazon's algorithms costs money.

Depth and breadth refer to how deeply you go with your analysis of the loop. Do you consider just music, or also other kinds of sound experiences? Do you include news, for example? Phone conversations? There are different depths that might be considered. Breadth refers to the different modalities of experience. In the imaginary digital soundtrack service that I talked about earlier, the breadth refers to the media, like audio, visual, and physical media. There are different dimensionalities of experiences we can mediate with different media. The media could include sounds related to entertainment, news, or work.

Granularity refers to how pinpointed the information is. The system might understand the sound decibel level of my entire house, or a room in the house, or within my body reach. Think of Airbnb. You use Airbnb because you need a house, a home, a kitchen, a dining table. If I want to host a party, I may not need a whole house; I just need a dining room with a dining table. Can Airbnb sense and respond to users' needs at that resolution? The goal is to sense what the customer really needs and then to match that with the precise resources required, minimizing waste.

JE: You talk about both sensing and responding. For responding, you have used the metaphor of printing. Obviously, printing isn't just printing a document or a thing--it is a broader concept in your meaning of the term. Can you talk about what you mean by printing as it ties in with co-creation at the point of use?

YY: Printing in my way of thinking is a conversion of digital insights into an actual physical manifestation of some kind to create value to users in the physical world. Once Spotify has insight about what you like to listen to, for example, that insight needs to be translated into actual music. The printing is done when the beats hit the airwave. The whole idea is the materialization of computed insights into a physical rendering of some form, something which is of value to users and that they can actually consume. To me, that's printing.

This notion of printing is related to the concept of procrastinated binding. Printing used to be done massively at the point of manufacturing. It was at manufacturing that all the insight from market research was converted into design and became a physical product. Value was captured when the product was sold. That was the end of the journey, and the producer didn't see or capture any of the value created during use. In the Digital First view, there is still a product, but the value capture is not only at the point of purchase, but also during use throughout the life of the product. The printing is delayed or procrastinated. And it is recurring. The printing involves mobilizing the different resources that are needed to create value in use for the customers. By necessity, it involves not only my product but also the products or services of other parties. The coordination and mobilization of the different parties and resources are done through algorithms, and they are done in run-time. As a manufacturer I want to be the one who coordinates the mobilization of those resources. I don't want to leave it to the user, because then I will not participate in creating value in use, and I won't have the right to capture any of the value. I also don't want to cede this role to other parties because they will be in the position to capture most of the value. I'd rather be the one who coordinates the experience, and I want to earn that role because I have better insight about customer needs.

JE: One more question. How should Digital First thinking affect what leaders of R&D or product development in physical product companies do? How should they think about their roles going forward?

YY: I think that the idea of traditional R&D needs to change. People need to get out of their labs and go into users' houses, because if they really want to do this Digital First transformation, the value is created at the point of use. How can you create a platform without seeing and understanding that action? The point of value creation is no longer at your factory; the point of value creation is at the point of consumption and use. As an R&D leader, you had better be there; you had better really understand what can be done beyond the product to deliver the experience. That is the most important, big thing R&D leaders need to do.

The IoT can be viewed as many different things, but from an R&D perspective, I look at IoT and connected products not only as a delivery platform but also as an R&D partner. If we are able to get rich data and feed it into analytical engines to sense what users like to do and generate possible digital solutions using generative algorithms, I think that we will discover a tremendous opportunity for IoT to create very different and much better consumption experiences. This is the big advantage that physical product companies will have in the next generation of digital.

Jim Euchner is editor-in-chief of Research-Technology Management and Honorary Professor at Aston University (UK). He previously held senior management positions in innovation leadership at Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, Pitney Bowes, and Bell Atlantic. He holds BS and MS degrees in mechanical and aerospace engineering from Cornell and Princeton Universities, respectively, and an MBA from Southern Methodist University. euchner@iriweb.org

Youngjin Yoo is the Elizabeth M. and William C. Treuhaft Professor in Entrepreneurship and Professor of Information Systems in the Department of Design & Innovation at the Weatherhead School of Management, Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland, Ohio. He is the founding faculty director of Case Western Reserve University's xLab. He is also a WBS Distinguished Research Environment Professor at Warwick Business School (UK), a visiting professor at the London School of Economics (UK), and an Association for Information Systems Fellow. He has worked as an innovation architect overseeing digital transformation at the University Hospitals of Cleveland, one of the largest teaching hospital systems in the US. He studies digital innovation and has published in leading academic journals such as MIS Quarterly, Information Systems Research, Organization Science, the Communications of the ACM, and the Academy of Management Journal. youngjin.yoo@case.edu

DOI: 10.1080/08956308.2020.1733885
